I saw your response to that guy on 1.18.17  11:02 pm asking about the real book chords.  not having much keyboard experience  i thought your idea of just playing all the songs was amazing and i gave it a shot. after playing about 30 of them i have a few questions1. #9 chords are kind of bothering me. am i supposed to play with the minor second clash right next to each other or spread it out, because it sounds better spread out but a lot of times i can't get to that position fast enough.
i would say the default way to play, for example, E7#9 would be (listed from low to high) g#, d, g. (left hand takes E, the bass)
2. same for 11s and 13s whats a good way to voice them?
there are many different types and situations. perhaps you could give me a specific example
3. i've just been doing block chords so far and that has been challenging enough. How do I play these charts in a more realistic groove (you mentioned bossa nova and I have no idea what that is)

just play something in time, so you can feel the time. sometimes there's 1 chord in a bar, sometimes there are 2. if you are just playing the chords with no time, then the song won't make sense at all. use whatever groove is the simplest and most comfortable for you, but also doesn't bore you

just try and see what works best where

This is going to seem like a really weird musical question, but I'm hoping to get some advice on Trills. Usually, I follow the same kinda mindset as you've said before of "trying to fit the chord/instrumentation that supports the melody/song at the time" (I think, it's been a while!) But I haven't been able to ever make a trill on either a brass instrument or a piano or keyboard to sound anything but really really jarring against the rest of the song... In your song "this is a song for my next album" you end the song with a really excellent trill on a keyboard that just Feels So Natural to the rest of the track! I absolutely know that I should be looking to find the instrumentation that supports the track as best as possible rather than Trying To Fit something that doesn't belong (as like forcing yourself to shoehorn a particular chord) but I feel like at this point there's just something that I'm fundamentally missing with my execution of a trill that always leads to it clashing Every Time. Any ideas on what might be my issue, or any tips that might help point me in the right direction? Thanks!

Whenever I try to create something artistic and start but get stuck in the middle my mind tends to wander.  At first I will be trying to find ideas to advance the project but I then begin to think of other art-ish things that have little or no relation to the project I am currently working on (like going from writing a poem to thinking of musical riffs).  I understand this isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it becomes a problem when I need to get a project done (I am a student).  Any advice you can give about this?

try much shorter projects first, they are much easier to finish, and you will get some practice and hone in on your process. then when you are ready you can move to longer projects, and you will complete them handily because you will know what you're doing by that time

help! i think of a bunch of new musical ideas when im walking between things and dont have a good way to record it or write it down! how do i remember my ideas for later?

this is very important, because this is usually where a large percentage of your ideas come from, so it is important to have a technique for this. Use a voice memo app (most phones have them) and be quick and professional about how you frame it. establish where the root of the key is, establish where the time is, and correctly count it off, so there is no confusion about where the key and time are oriented. any hints about the groove or tempo are also very helpful, (perhaps compare it to another song's tempo, if that helps) and any other hints about how the idea is oriented in the song ('this is the top of of the chorus' or 'this would the the end title line of a chorus' or 'this would be a verse line' or any other hints you can think of). and if there are any specific chord things, mention that too, like if you know the whole thing starts on the 4 chord, or something like that. but most importantly remember to orient the key (sing a quick do re mi reference or something) and properly count off the time, and sing the thing, preferably a couple of times. overall your total demo + description should be about 15 to 20 seconds

there is pressure from all sides. some people want the video to come out sooner. some people want me to work less, and 'take vacations.' some people want me to give opinions about the latest films and tv shows. some people want me to make more short videos. some people want me to make songs. some people want me to make more journal clips. some people want me to answer more questions. some people think i answer too many questions. some people want me to collaborate with their favorite artists. some people want me to make videos for their business. these are some of the many kinds of pressure i receive on a daily basis
Or do you not care what others think, and care only to work at a pace that suits you?  Or perhaps a combination of both?

but the only kind of pressure i pay attention to is the pressure that was present before any of those, which is whoops i have no social life but my mind has been exploding for as long as i can remember, and it needs to be put on display ASAP in as many ways as possible until people understand

I know the new vid is comin', so i will ask about something else. peanut butter song: you recorded the jar hits on to a MIDI track and then just moved the notes to form the major and then add 9 chords, right? It seems more practical than just playing chords in sync or trying to re-sync 'em. just that. keep it awesome and hellyeahish.

the song was actually recorded around early 2010. it was called "this song yeah" and it's hardly a song, it's just me slamming a major chord several times in a row. During 2014, as part of the weekly content schedule, one of the videos each week is supposed to be a 'music video' which is when you make a video to go along to a song that's already recorded. so for a thrill, i decided to try an instrumental song. i picked "this song yeah." the idea that worked best was a jar of peanut butter. when the video was done, it only made sense to change the title. most of the time i aim for strict musical accuracy in my videos, because it is usually more thrilling, especially for musician viewers, but in this particular video the notes are ignored. mainly because it is impossible to play a major triad with a peanut butter jar

Can you drop some more mad hints and give us an idea on how close you are to finishing the new History of [blank] video? The last one that really gave us an idea of the progress you made was a checklist comparing it to the one for history of Japan.

the 'graphics' phase was finished on feb 7. after that, the process is a little bit more confusing to explain. it's a lot of smaller things -- final narration, jingle vocals, editing jingles and narration, mixing, re-alignment to fit final narration timing, and the score. the score is the most subtantial item of all of those, but not as large as 'graphics.' it is hard to exactly explain the process because i have been bouncing around depending on whether it's day or night (vocal recording, etc) and also i was sick and had lingering sick voice for a couple weeks, so during that time i made an early detour into doing the score, somewhere around feb 19. so i basically locked up the narration timing up until 7:50 (that was as far as i had gotten) and started on the score. by the time i reached 7:50 in the score (this was around march 2 i guess), i was able to resume vocals, and was bouncing around between doing jingles and narration.  narration is now solidly in place with correct timing, video re-alignment to fit that new timing is done, now starting on the rest of the score, from 8min to the end. once the score is done, it is just the small little tasks like year labels, other labels, graphics adjustments, mixing, etc etc etc but these small tasks tend to fly by very fast, and once the score is done it tends to be a slippery slope to the end of the process. this is what i know from experience on doing the previous long video of this type. i hope that makes sense

yesterday I was in the Dollar Tree� with my grandma and we were checking out and the cashier looks at me and I'm thinking "what the fuck that guy looks like bill" and I look at his name tag whilst he's is engaged in conversation with my grandma and it says "RYEN" and I'm like thinking... "fuck, this dude is either not bill Wurtz or he's bill Wurtz under cover." And then he looks at me. And I stare at him. And he says "I like your shirt, man. I've listened to Abbey Road so many times. Rock on" and I just keep staring at him and I look to my grandma and to him and I'm sure I looked like I was going insane and then he starts talking again and he's like "I even love that stupid octopuses garden song" and I'm like "bill?" And he's like "what" and my grandma is like "no it was the other guy in the Beatles who wrote that song" and then he gets in an argument with my grandma about who wrote that song and I'm just standing there watching him scan my grandmas adult diapers and scream at her and in my head I'm thinking "THIS IS BILL FUCKING WURTZ or possibly his twin brother that lives in Florida AND HE KNOWS ALL THE SECRETS TO THE UNIVERSE" because he was winning the argument and I assumed he knew everything else as well. and basically: this shook me, bill.

i don't say rock on, and i'm not terribly interested in abbey road. in general, the points of interest for me on that record are 'her majesty,' 'maxwell silverhammer,' 'she came in thru the bathroom window,' 'polythene pam', and the wild items list in the verses (not the chorus) of 'come together'. but unlike ryen, i am not too interested in the entire album

to the person who asked about death being necessary: death by ageing is caused by deterioration of the telomeres that cap chromosomes, which means that eventually the cells aren't able to divide anymore, so they die. it's called cell senescence (and some cells like rat brain cells don't have this problem and they can keep on dividing forever). so it is possible that in the future we could maybe prevent death, by altering DNA so that the telomeres don't go bad. (telomeres shorten after each cell replication). I don't know if you'll post this but I think it's cool info that people don't hear about unless they search for it specifically

How did you go about animating the notation in your classic "the high class stuff"?

i will explain a single page first (the multi-page spread is another issue)... let's say there is just one page of notation, like 8 bars or whatever.... I make the notation in a notation program, and screenshot it. (then i actually make several alignment adjustments in graphics, because notation programs are incredibly finicky, it's easier to adjust things in graphics)... then i save it how i want. then i use graphics to erase the last note (and any chord that goes along with it.) i erase notes on a staff by just dragging empty staff over it. and i "save as" and then add a 1 to the file name. repeat, keep erasing the next note and 'save as'. then you have a stack of files all in order. then import. then allign the timing. it's the exact same way i do text, but with text i type it out and screenshot each frame, and delete words (easier, instead of erasing them). the delete technique would not work in a notation program, because the notes and alignment will change as you delete them. that's why i use graphics. it's not that hard, and i'm not even using a graphics program. just an image preview program, and i'm just copying and pasting boxes. the mccartney video was a bit more ambitious because i wanted to do a steady scroll. so i thought it would be good to make one huge image file that is the entire length of the score. and then do the erase per frame technique.... so then all the frames were huge... and then export that to a really high res video and scroll the video??? i don't remember if this was successful, but you run into major problems when you try to do huge things like that. processing power limitations, etc. Same sort of crisis occured when i was trying to do the zoom out on the japanese army. i ended up having to somehow break the task into smaller pieces. if i recall. i somehow succeeded in getting a steady scroll on the notation, only to find out that it was too hard to read when it's moving like that!! so i ended up keeping it still and then sliding forward page by page. if i had known the steady scroll wasn't going to work, i probably would have broken it into pages from the start

If you had to choose between having absolutely perfect pitch but always getting annoyed when someone is out of tune at all, or always being out of tune but being able to enjoy music as you do now, what would you choose?

i'm not sure you are understanding quite how perfect pitch works. the name of perfect pitch is misleading. it makes more sense to call it 'absolute pitch.' and you don't need to have absolute pitch to know whether something is out of tune with itself. only to know whether it is overall tuned to A=440hz. and whether or not something is tuned to A=440hz does not affect whether or not it sounds 'in tune'. anyone claiming to be annoyed by something because it is not tuned to A=440 is lying, and using it as an excuse to brag that they have absolute pitch. in fact some people even claim things are not A=440 when they actually are, especially nowadays, with most music being made on computers where all the instruments are by default set to A=440

Who is the girl you were writing about in the conclusion of the song, "i don't wanna go to school"?

i only ever had one conversation with her, but the topic of school came up, and when she found out that i was 'not currently in school' she sort of made an implication that i obviously 'should go back to school', and it would be clearly be wrong not to. and in that moment i instantly realized a certain social pressure that goes very sharply against my life-path, and i raced inside and wrote the first few lines of that song. it actually wasn't until years later that the ending was written, but when writing the ending i chose to envoke further details about the actual situation that inspired the song. this is a strategy i often use when finishing songs that were started years earlier. i hope that makes sense
